A rugged Bluetooth speaker: Sure, everyone owns a bluetooth speaker these days‚Äîbut handypeople will appreciate a Bluetooth speaker that‚Äôs durable enough for a worksite and that also uses the same batteries as their power tools.

Anti-fatigue mat: Ah, the simple joys of standing hunched over a workbench for hours at a time. An anti-fatigue mat will spare your DIYer‚Äôs back and leave them refreshed after every job.

Boot and glove dryer: There‚Äôs nothing worse than getting up to continue a big project only to discover that your boots and gloves are still soaked from the day before. Drying those items out in an hour or less? Magical.

Beverage holster: Anyone who‚Äôs done work around their house knows that DIY work is fueled by refreshing beverages. Whatever your drink of choice, make it easy to have on hand at all times with this nifty holster.

title: Newcastle's Wade set to resume chase for try record
description: Christian Wade has 93 tries, eight behind Chris Ashton's Prem record of 101, as he begins his Newcastle Red Bulls career.
fullText:
Christian Wade is back in rugby union and has Chris Ashton's record as the all-time leading try-scorer in Prem Rugby firmly in his sights.

Wade is the most eye-catching arrival at Newcastle Red Bulls since the takeover by the energy drinks giant after the winger enjoyed a brief stint in rugby league with Wigan Warriors.

He is expected to make his Newcastle debut in their European Challenge Cup game against South African side Lions on Saturday (17:30 GMT), in what would be a tune-up for the three Prem games that follow over Christmas and new year.

The 34-year-old winger has touched down 93 times in the Prem, eight behind Ashton's tally of 101, and he is not hiding his ambition after linking up with his new team-mates at Kingston Park.

"I saw this as a next step for me," he told BBC Look North. "It's a great opportunity to come, bring my experience, have an impact and get that record."

title: Belfast to host inaugural 'three-on-three' ice hockey World Cup
description: The SSE Arena in Belfast will host ice hockey's inaugural 3ICE World Cup on Saturday, 4 and Sunday, 5 July 2026.
fullText:
The SSE Arena in Belfast will host ice hockey's inaugural 3ICE World Cup next summer.

Belfast Giants head coach Adam Keefe will take charge of Great Britain with USA, Canada, Sweden, Finland, Switzerland, Germany, and Austria also taking part in the two-day competition on 4 and 5 July.

Launched in 2022, 3ICE centres around the three-on-three format that ice hockey fans are accustomed to seeing when games go to overtime.

There are two eight-minute period of continuous play, with the clock stopping only for penalties and injuries. Squads are seven players strong with six skaters and one goaltender.

"It's exciting for the city to get to host an event like this," Keefe told BBC Sport NI.

"Three-on-three ice hockey is exciting and fast. You can see at the Belfast Giants, when it goes to overtime, it's pretty exciting and nerve-wracking as a coach, but it's something to get behind.

"As a coach, sometimes you go into those games and it's a flip of the coin who is going to win because three-on three-changes the game dramatically and makes for some exciting entertainment."

title: Cardiff proving they will not be bullied - Wintle
description: Cardiff City are proving they will not be "bullied" by League One's physically-imposing teams, says Ryan Wintle.
fullText:
Cardiff City are proving they will not be "bullied" by League One's more physically-imposing teams, says Bluebirds midfielder Ryan Wintle.

Cardiff are four points clear at the top of the table as they aim to make an instant return to the Championship following last season's relegation.

Head coach Brian Barry-Murphy, who was appointed in the summer, has led his team to the summit by instilling an adventurous, possession-based style of play.

He has also built his team around young players and academy graduates, who have occasionally struggled against the division's direct and abrasive sides.

But Cardiff overcame one such team, Stevenage ‚Äì who were until then third in the table and unbeaten at home ‚Äì in a hard-fought 1-0 away win on Tuesday to underline their promotion credentials.

"Stevenage away, people would say it was a tough place and they'd just keep loading the ball on top of us," said Wintle, as the Bluebirds prepared to host Doncaster on Saturday (15:00 GMT).

"It wasn't a pretty game, but we dug in well and our quality showed at the end with Cal [Callum Robinson] coming on and scoring a great finish.

"The belief is that as long as you do the hard stuff and the dirty stuff, that teams are going to try and bully us, then our football will show and we'll win the game.

"Everyone's going to have their own way of playing and that's credit to them. They [Stevenage] are near the top of the league for doing that well.

"But we can't play like that ‚Äì it's not us. We've got a group that would probably struggle to play like that, if we were like that we'd be towards the bottom of the table.

"So we've got to play the way that gets the best out of our players and that's the way we play at the minute and we're doing it well."

title: Wainwright boost after 'unacceptable' Dragons loss
description: Wales number eight Aaron Wainwright is set to boost the Dragons' bid for a first win of 2025 against Lyon in the Challenge Cup.
fullText:
European Challenge Cup: Dragons v Lyon

Venue: Rodney Parade, Newport Date: Sunday, 14 December Kick-off: 15:15 GMT

Coverage: Live commentary on BBC Sport website and app.

Wales number eight Aaron Wainwright will boost Dragons' bid to bounce back from an "unacceptable" opening European Challenge Cup defeat when hosting Lyon on Sunday.

The Rodney Parade club are still without a win in 2025 and last weekend were thrashed 41-17 by Perpignan, who have lost all 11 games in the Top 14 this season.

Dragons drew two home games in the first block of the United Rugby Championship (URC), but now hunt a first success since winning at Newcastle in the Challenge Cup last December.

Wainwright was rested for the trip to Perpignan after his autumn exertions with Wales and will return for Dragons on Sunday.

"We are excited to have 'Waino' back in. He's a good strong Gwent man and is important to the group, and important to the nation," said head coach Filo Tiatia.

Welsh rugby in danger of losing Morgan and Lake

Tierney will return to lead WRU in January

Gloucester's Llewellyn & Joseph out 'for decent period'

Dragons have played 19 fixtures in 2025 and lost 17 of them, with chances blown for late home victories in draws against Sharks and Ospreys in the first block of the URC.

Tiatia has enjoyed just one victory since taking over from Dai Flanagan after the first block of 2024-25 and the pressure is mounting.

The head coach insisted an "honest review" had been held into the error-strewn display at a previously winless Perpignan, who need a miracle to avoid Top 14 relegation.

"The result wasn't great and our performance wasn't great," said Tiatia. "As a group we know that it was unacceptable around some of the things we said we were going to do, but didn't do.

"This is another exciting opportunity and we can't have a day off when we perform in this jersey. Lyon is an opportunity to put some wrongs right."

Dragons have a six-day turnaround from the Lyon fixture to a home URC game against Connacht that is followed by festive derbies at Cardiff and Scarlets at Rodney Parade.

"We are in the third week of a 10-week block and it's an opportunity for us to make a turn," said Tiatia.

"I am pretty positive around our preparation. It's time to put a line in the sand, they have been sharp this week and we are looking forward to the game."

Dragons' issues at hooker worsened last weekend when Sam Scarfe, who was making his first professional start, went off with a head injury.

He is still going through return-to-play protocols while Elliot Dee and James Benjamin are out until the New Year and Oli Burrows and Brodie Coghlan are doubts for this weekend.

That leaves on-loan Will Austin, a former Wales Under-20s international who has made two appearances off the bench after signing a short-term deal from Sale Sharks, as the only definite option and Dragons hope to make another emergency signing.

title: Powell and Lyles helping Jamaica hurricane victims
description: Two-time 100m world record holder Asafa Powell teams up with Olympic gold-winning sprinter Noah Lyles to help Hurricane Melissa victims in Jamaica.
fullText:
Two-time 100m world record holder Asafa Powell has teamed up with Olympic gold medal-winning sprinter Noah Lyles to help those affected by Hurricane Melissa in Jamaica.

The category-five hurricane hit the Caribbean island in October, killing at least 28 people.

Powell, a member of Jamaica's 4x100m gold medal-winning team at the 2016 Olympics, lives in capital city Kingston and has visited areas most heavily hit to help those affected.

"My heart was just overwhelmed with sadness," Powell told BBC World Service.

"I tried not to focus too much on the devastation and tried to see how I could best assist.

"When you see mothers with young babies, or people who can't even shower and have had mud on them for days - it is something that will make you cry."

title: Ireland beat England in Pro League shootout
description: Ireland earn their first points in the FIH Pro League as they edge out England 4-3 in a dramatic shootout after a 1-1 draw in Dublin.
fullText:
Ireland earned their first points in the FIH Pro League as they edged out England 4-3 in a dramatic shootout after a 1-1 draw in Dublin.

Sarah Torrans gave the home side a first-half lead before Ellie Rayer equalised for England in the third quarter.

In heavy rain at the Sport Ireland campus, both sides looked happy with a point at the end, but it was Ireland who held their nerve in the shootout with goalkeeper Lizzie Murphy making the final stop to give the hosts the second point.

Charlotte Beggs, Mikayla Power and Hannah McLoughlin (2) scored for Ireland in the shootout, while Darcy Bourne, Rayer and Lily Owsley converted for England.

"We‚Äôre delighted. We started the game with a lot of energy and that was exactly what we wanted to do,‚Äù said Torrans.

"Unfortunately we couldn't hold them out for the win and but look it's a number of steps forward for us so we're happy right now."

title: Cyborg confirms 2026 retirement plan to become a vet
description: Cris Cyborg says she plans to bring her historic career to a close next year to follow "different dreams", including becoming a vet.
fullText:
Cris Cyborg says she plans to end her glittering career next year to follow "different dreams", including becoming a veterinarian.

Cyborg, 40, has enjoyed championship victories across multiple promotions during a 20-year career.

The Brazilian, victorious in her past eight bouts, has won 28 of her 31 fights and hasn't suffered defeat since losing to Amanda Nunes in 2018.

Cyborg fights Australia's Sara Collins in Lyon on Saturday for the PFL women's featherweight title in a bout which she says will be the penultimate of her MMA career.

"My last fight, I said to everybody that I'm starting my legacy tour because I have two fights left on my contract and I'm preparing myself to retire and close this chapter," Cyborg told MMA Fighting.

"For me, next year is going to be the last year for everything.

"In July I turned 40 so next year is going to be 41. I don't have any bad injuries in my career. I'm very blessed about this. I never did one surgery from one injury so thank you God."

Cyborg is the owner of a large ranch in Brazil and plans to pursue a degree from a veterinary school when she gives up MMA.

"Next year is going to be 21 years doing the same thing every day and I have different dreams. Among the dreams, I want to be a vet and I still want to do this," she added.

title: Vardy is first English Serie A player of the month
description: Cremonese striker Jamie Vardy is the Serie A player of the month for November, becoming the first English player to win the award.
fullText:
Cremonese striker Jamie Vardy has been named as the Serie A player of the month for November, becoming the first English player to win the award.

The former Leicester City captain played three matches in the Italian top flight last month, scoring one goal against Juventus.

Fellow nominees for the award, which combines fan votes with statistical data, included AC Milan goalkeeper Mike Maignan, Inter Milan's Lautaro Martinez, Napoli winger David Neres, Genoa's Leo Ostigard and Nicolo Zaniolo of Udinese.

"Vardy is truly a player from another era," Serie A chief executive Luigi de Siervo said.

title: More signings to follow Martin - Saracens boss McCall
description: England second row George Martin will be followed by more signings in the coming weeks as Saracens aim to restore their glory days, says boss Mark McCall.
fullText:
Investec Champions Cup: Sharks v Saracens

Venue: Hollywoodbets Kings Park, Durban Date: Saturday, 13 December Kick-off: 15:15 GMT

George Martin will be followed by more signings in the coming weeks as Saracens aim to restore their glory days, says director of rugby Mark McCall.

England second row Martin's arrival from Leicester for the start of next season was confirmed on Tuesday, while Saracens have been heavily linked to Gloucester scrum-half Tomos Williams, whose contract at Kingsholm expires in the summer., external

With Tom Willis bound for Bordeaux-Begles, back rows Jac Morgan and Hoskins Sotutu have been mentioned as possible reinforcements.

However, according to reports, Gloucester lead the race for Morgan, as Newcastle do for Sotutu., external

"There's possibly one, maybe two signings hopefully, either now or after Christmas," said McCall.

"I think the last time we had this scale of a rebuild was around 2015 and we managed to keep that group together for a while.

"But, like any group, it gets to the end of their life cycle, with the likes of Sean Maitland, Mako Vunipola, Billy Vunipola leaving the club.

"We're about 18 months into this next group... we've got plenty of youngsters that you've seen this year coming through - Jack Bracken, Tobias Elliott, Angus Hall, Noah Caluori, Nathan Michelow, Charlie Bracken - we are excited by the players we are producing.

"We want to build from within as much as possible, but occasionally you just need to go to the outside as well."

Last season was Saracens' first since 2009, excluding those affected by the club's 2020 demotion to the Championship for salary cap breaches, in which they fell short of the play-offs.

Between 2015 and 2019, Saracens won four English titles and three Champions Cups.

Saracens confirm signing of England lock Martin

England and Leicester lock Martin ruled out until 2026

Welsh rugby in danger of losing Morgan and Lake

McCall says Martin's ability to play at blind-side flanker, his physicality and his desire to win those top prizes motivated Saracens' move for him.

"He's the perfect age, he's 24, already with a lot of experience behind him, both at club level and international level. He's a real tough abrasive hard-hitting back-five forward," McCall said.

"We were super impressed with him when we met, just what he wants to achieve in the years ahead and how hungry he is."

Martin has been out since February with a shoulder issue and missed six weeks with a knee injury at the start of 2024.

However McCall says Saracens have done their "due diligence" before investing.

"We've talked to all the people that we needed to talk to, be assured that everything's going to be fine for that point," he said.

After their opening-round Champions Cup win over Clermont Auvergne last weekend, Saracens take on South Africa side Sharks in Durban on Saturday.

While Sharks suffered a 56-19 defeat by Toulouse last week and have won only once in their first six games in the United Rugby Championship, South Africa captain Siya Kolisi and a clutch of his international team-mates are available once more.

Grant Williams, Andre Esthuizen and Bongi Mbonambi could all feature.

"They've got one of the best squads in the competition, man for man," said McCall.

"I know they've had a difficult start to their season, but they're really massively disrupted by the Springbok programme and how many players are unavailable."

title: Smith needs to be England's heartbeat - Prior
description: Matt Prior says Jamie Smith needs to relish being the "heartbeat" of England's team and be up for "the fight" of trying to help the tourists recover from 2-0 down in the Ashes.
fullText:
Former England wicketkeeper Matt Prior says Jamie Smith needs to relish being the "heartbeat" of England's team and be up for "the fight" of trying to help the tourists recover from 2-0 down in the Ashes series.

Smith has struggled in recent matches, failing to pass 33 in his past eight Test innings, while mistakes have crept in behind the stumps with the Surrey man dropping Australia's Travis Head in the second Test in Brisbane.

"The keeper's role has always been the heartbeat of that group on the field," Prior, who won three Ashes series with England in a 79-Test career, told the BBC's Stumped podcast.

"You're the drummer of the band, you help the captain and bowlers with angles. You know how the bowlers are getting on, how they're coming, are they still in rhythm, are they hitting the gloves well, are they not? Are the plans and tactics right for any given batsman, do they need changing?

"If you're internalising everything and just focusing on your own game, you can't concentrate on anything external which is hugely important to the captain, bowlers and the rest of the team.

"Jamie Smith, in that role as wicketkeeper, needs to want to be out there, want to be in the middle and want to be in the fight."

England need to win the third Test in Adelaide to retain a chance of winning the Ashes and Prior said a re-focused Smith was vital to turning round England's fortunes in the series after two opening defeats.

"The best thing Jamie Smith can do is prep, make sure that your game's in good order," said Prior.

"Once that's done, you can't do any more than that - if you make a mistake, it's because you're human. When you get into the game then it's about everything external.

"Sometimes you have to force yourself massively, but just focus on 'Is Jofra hitting the gloves well? Is he swinging it back, is it going across, is the ball swinging, is it not?'

"Grab the fielders, Ben Duckett, Ollie Pope, Zak Crawley - 'Right we're going to go pick a fight with Steve Smith'. That's the stuff you have to do."

Speaking on the Stick to Cricket podcast, former Australia wicketkeeper Ian Healy said Smith needed to contribute tactically, but could rely on his team-mates to put pressure on the opposition.

"If you care for your team and care for your role as a wicketkeeper, you're going to give that bowler some advice, you're going to hatch a plan together. And the plan might not work but you feel like you're focused," said Healy.

"Being boisterous or talkative, someone's got to do it - when they're batting, they need to hear a presence. If you hear silence behind you then you're halfway through it."

Meanwhile, Healy added that Smith would be thinking of the excellent form of opposite number Alex Carey: "It's a niggle in the back of your head.

"I've got to lift or I'm gone here, or my confidence is low ‚Äì this bloke's making it look really easy. You have got an eye on the opposition keeper for sure."

title: Sutton's predictions v England Gaming star Daniel 'Stingray' Ray
description: BBC Sport football expert Chris Sutton takes on England Gaming star Daniel 'Stingray' Ray - and AI - with his predictions for this weekend's Premier League fixtures.
fullText:
Sunday brings the first Wear-Tyne derby since 2024 but will it be Sunderland or Newcastle celebrating afterwards?

"For most of last season you couldn't have imagined Sunderland getting promoted and being competitive with Eddie Howe's Newcastle, let alone being above them in the table," said BBC Sport football expert Chris Sutton.

"It is very different now, and the way Sunderland play makes me think they've got a real chance."

Sutton is making predictions for all 380 Premier League games this season, against AI, BBC Sport readers and a variety of guests.

For week 16, he takes on England Gaming star Daniel 'Stingray' Ray.

Ray is going for glory for the eLions - the Football Association's official esports team - at EA Sports FC in the Uefa eEuro 2025 finals tournament, which takes place at Twickenham Stadium on Saturday.

You can watch the action on Uefa's YouTube, IG Live and TikTok channels, as well as EA Sports FC Twitch and YouTube and England's Twitch.

Do you agree with their scores? You can make your own predictions below.

The most popular scoreline selected for each game is used in the scoreboards and tables at the bottom of this page.

A correct result (picking a win, draw or defeat) is worth 10 points. The exact score earns 40 points.

title: Bears QB Caleb Williams shares lessons learned in loss to Packers
description: Bears quarterback Caleb Williams spoke about his positive takeaways from last Sunday's loss to the Packers.
fullText:
Following the Chicago Bears' disappointing loss to the Green Bay Packers last Sunday, quarterback Caleb Williams is finding value in losing to their bitter rival.

Williams struggled in the first half before leading an impressive second-half comeback that included three scoring drives, including the game-tying touchdown. But he came up short on the final play of the game, throwing an interception to Keisean Nixon in the end zone in what would've been a game-tying touchdown to tight end Cole Kmet.

Not only was the game a big one in terms of the rivalry between the Bears and Packers, but it had major implications on the playoff race in the NFC and NFC North. The loss to Green Bay knocked the Bears down from the top seed in the conference to the seventh, barely hanging onto their playoff hopes.

Following the game, Williams discussed the positive takeaways from the high-stakes matchup and how it helps prepare him for the stretch run.

"Yeah, you know obviously our goal is to win every single game, and our goal is to win these games, and you know, get to the playoffs," Williams said. "It‚Äôs a playoff atmosphere, going versus a rival and things like that. So, it‚Äôs good for us to be able to find ways to rally and obviously we want to focus on having a better outcome and starting faster and all these different things. But it‚Äôs definitely useful for us, just in case we go on the road at some point and in the playoffs and things like that. It‚Äôs something that we are going to use in the future and throughout my career. But we got to focus on this next game up to get to that point."

Following an abysmal rookie season, which saw just five wins and multiple coaches fired, Williams has plenty of significance each and every week for the rest of the season. Getting started faster will be a big part of how the Bears can close out their season on a high note, and while Williams may not reach all his individual goals, getting the team to the playoffs is the best accomplishment he could have.

Follow Bears Wire on¬†Twitter,¬†Facebook¬†and¬†Instagram

This article originally appeared on Bears Wire: Bears QB Caleb Williams shares lessons learned in loss to Packers

title: Can a nepo baby be an underdog? The remarkable rise of Shedeur Sanders
description: The quarterback was seen as living off his father‚Äôs name when he entered the NFL. But he has slowly started to prove himself at the Cleveland Browns
fullText:
It seems the goalposts are always moving on Shedeur Sanders, the Cleveland Browns‚Äô rookie quarterback who keeps throwing people off.

He excelled at two colleges to establish himself as a top NFL prospect, only to wind up getting picked in the fifth round of this year‚Äôs NFL draft in one of the most dramatic stock crashes in league history. He then distinguished himself in training camp, only to wind up as the back-up to the back-up. When Sanders was finally pressed into injury relief duty last month and led the Browns to just their third win of the season, the caveat was that his breakthrough had come at the expense of the even-worse Las Vegas Raiders. Last week against the struggling Tennessee Titans, Sanders became the first Browns quarterback to throw for more than 300 yards and three touchdowns and rush for another score in the same game since 1950. But for many, the bigger headline was that he lost. Again.

Earlier this week Sanders was named the Browns starter for the rest of the season, inviting even more scrutiny of a an already polarizing player. His supporters say Sanders is entitled to his shot; his critics say he lacks the skills to play in the NFL, question his attitude and paint him as a spoiled rich kid. Every argument seems to excavate deeper feelings about Deion Sanders, his Prime Time father who paved the way for his son‚Äôs success. In the age of the nepo baby, Shedeur makes for a strange underdog story.

There are expectations that come with being a starting quarterback in the NFL, after all. In addition to the requisite physical attributes and arm talent, the cliche dictates that quarterbacks are men of character ‚Äì players who speak in the first person plural, deflect credit, absorb blame and lead with modesty. It‚Äôs how the quarterback position became shorthand for a standard of American leadership that was largely reserved for conservative white men until recently. But Shedeur doesn‚Äôt even resemble the Black quarterbacks who have in the last few years broken from that tradition and transformed the league. Instead, in character at least, he resembles his father. Deion is a flashy, brash and supremely self-confident two-sport superstar universally recognized as one of the best players in NFL history.

After becoming the first Browns quarterback to win his first start since the team‚Äôs 1999 relaunch, a soundbite of Shedeur effectively congratulating himself for playing well despite his limited practice time overshadowed the more diplomatic remarks he‚Äôd make in praise of the team later. (‚ÄúImagine what a full offseason looks like,‚Äù he beamed. ‚ÄúIt gets dangerous!‚Äù) When he was asked last Sunday if a botched two-point conversion attempt had worked during practice, he laughed. (‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think you call plays in a game that didn‚Äôt work in practice,‚Äù he cracked.) After being criticized for his remarks in the media earlier this season, he was asked about the Browns‚Äô quarterback situation. Sanders repeatedly answered by grinning and then silently moving his mouth in response ‚Äì which had fans jokingly referring to him as Mime Time in a nod to his father.

‚ÄúWe want our quarterbacks to be very, very humble,‚Äù says Louis Moore, the Michigan State history professor and author of The Great Black Hope: Doug Williams, Vince Evans, and the Making of the Black Quarterback. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs not that. He‚Äôs grown up believing that he‚Äôs allowed to have confidence in himself. The world beats down a lot of young Black kids, and Deion never let it happen.‚Äù

The biased nature of the scrutiny on Shedeur, especially when things don‚Äôt go his way, often results in fans bringing up racism. They further wonder whether Browns head coach Kevin Stefanski holds a grudge against the Sanders family because his father-in-law, Tim McCarver, had an infamous run-in with Deion during the latter‚Äôs baseball career.

But the issue isn‚Äôt quite so black and white. Somehow, the Sanders family manage to inspire Obama-level respect and enthusiasm among Black Americans (who helped make Shedeur‚Äôs Browns jersey a bestseller) while also having Donald Trump in their corner. The current president hasn‚Äôt hesitated to cannonball into the Shedeur Sanders discourse, calling NFL owners ‚Äústupid‚Äù for letting him fall in the draft and trumpeting ‚ÄúI TOLD YOU SO!‚Äù on social media after Shedeur led the Browns past the Raiders. Trump couldn‚Äôt let those moments pass without making some mention of Shedeur‚Äôs ‚Äúexceptional genes‚Äù in what was otherwise a forceful show of support.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just thankful for [Trump] even taking time out of his day to speak out,‚Äù said Shedeur, reveling in his nepo baby status. While Peyton Manning was determined to overshadow his father Archie‚Äôs fruitless years with the New Orleans Saints and Bronny James shrinks from the allusions to the more prominent Lakers player in his family, Shedeur has been happy to share a spotlight with his famous father for more than a decade.

A good chunk of his adolescence was documented on Deion‚Äôs Family Playbook, a reality TV series that ran on Oprah‚Äôs cable channel. Shedeur then played under his father when Deion coached at Mississippi‚Äôs Jackson State University and the University of Colorado, and the pair were instrumental in reviving both of those programs. Wherever Shedeur goes, there‚Äôs usually a camera following him ‚Äì and oftentimes his older brother Deion Sanders Jr, the architect of the family‚Äôs vast online media presence, is the one holding the camera. Around family, Shedeur reverts from a football star to a little brother who gets razzed about his fashion choices and his position on his father‚Äôs sibling power rankings.

Being Deion Sanders‚Äôs son made Shedeur savvy to how NFL storylines are shaped, and the one he‚Äôs crafted about himself strikes the media ‚Äì who are used to taking charge of the narrative ‚Äì as presumptuous. He calls himself ‚Äúlegendary‚Äù, shrugs off brickbats (‚ÄúYou think I‚Äôm worried about what critics say?‚Äù) and throws words like ‚Äúdestiny‚Äù around when projecting his career path. Resentments linger about his starry approach to the draft process that may well have cost him the chance to be picked higher. It was thought that Deion was the one quarterbacking things behind the scenes at this year‚Äôs draft, but he has since revealed that it was Shedeur who may have rebuffed higher draft opportunities in Philadelphia and Baltimore because he didn‚Äôt want to sit behind two established starters, Jalen Hurts and Lamar Jackson ‚Äì a pretty smart read as it turns out.

‚ÄúI know the fight behind the fight,‚Äù Deion Sanders said earlier this season. ‚ÄúI know what‚Äôs been transpiring behind the curtains, and I‚Äôm just proud of him. Because he‚Äôs not just saying the right things, he‚Äôs doing and living the right things. That‚Äôs just who he is ‚Ä¶ He‚Äôs a Sanders.‚Äù

Shedeur has only played in four NFL games, two of those against bad teams, which is too small a sample size to make concrete pronouncements about his career. But his performances so far for the Browns, a team who have sunk the careers of countless quarterbacks, hint that he is dramatically better than his lowly draft position suggests. And while his chance to finish out the season is the first true vote of confidence he has received since joining the organization, there‚Äôs a sense that he isn‚Äôt so much playing for his Browns future as he is playing for the chance to thrive elsewhere. That‚Äôs because the Browns made a $230m commitment to the injured Deshaun Watson and are determined to see if they can get their money‚Äôs worth when he returns to fitness. With this season long lost, really all that Shedeur has to play for is trade value, pride and teammate Myles Garrett shattering the single-season sack record ‚Äì but of course that‚Äôs the popular spin.

For Shedeur, it‚Äôs just the latest chapter in a story that ends with him going down as the one of the biggest underdog success stories in sports ‚Äì the draft afterthought who became an NFL legend. (Sound familiar?) That dissonance of an underdog with privilege shows the extent to which nepo babies have taken over the narrative.

title: Browns vs. Titans: 5 takeaways from Cleveland's NFL Week 14 loss
description: The Browns lost yet another one, and this time to the measly Titans. So, yeah, we have some thoughts.
fullText:
The Cleveland Browns' 31-29 loss to the Tennessee Titans in Week 14 was a study in frustrating contradictions.

On one hand, the team showed flashes of a potentially bright future, particularly on the offensive side of the ball. Rookie quarterback Shedeur Sanders delivered a statistical performance that should give the organization and its fans genuine hope for the future, leading the offense on a thrilling, if ultimately incomplete, fourth-quarter comeback attempt. His connection with fellow rookie Harold Fannin Jr. was explosive and dynamic.

On the other hand, the loss starkly illuminated the systemic flaws that have plagued the Browns throughout this disappointing season. The defense, usually a bedrock of strength, struggled significantly, particularly against the run game, allowing a career-day for Titans running back Tony Pollard. Furthermore, the persistent issues on the offensive line and costly mistakes, including a momentum-killing interception and two failed two-point conversions, proved to be the difference against a struggling Titans team.

This defeat, dropping the Browns to 3-10, was a painful reminder that potential, even when dazzling, is no substitute for consistency and flawless execution, especially when facing a team desperate for a win.

Here are five key takeaways from the snowy, frustrating afternoon at Huntington Bank Field.

Shedeur Sanders showed another significant step in his development on Sunday, logging the best statistical game by a rookie quarterback this year with 364 yards passing and three touchdowns, plus a rushing score.

23/42, 364 pass yds, 3 pass td, 29 rush yds, 1 rush td, 1 int

more highlights on https://t.co/xMzvHOeNay pic.twitter.com/mfCA7cgkGc

‚Äî Cleveland Browns (@Browns) December 8, 2025

Sanders showed up when the team called his number, orchestrating two late touchdown drives. However, the one play he definitely wants back is a costly third-quarter interception on what looked to be a scramble drill attempt, where he overshot his man, flipping the game's momentum.

Sanders is still holding onto the ball longer and more often than any other quarterback in the league, leading to unnecessary pressure, sacks, and backbreaking turnovers. But if his can be ironed out further and his internal clock can be sped up, the Browns might just have their future quarterback already at the helm, proving he can handle the NFL stage.

The rookie tight end out of Bowling Green, Harold Fannin Jr., continued his impressive run as a leading pass-catcher for the Browns.

Fannin racked up 114 yards and a touchdown on eight receptions against the Titans, marking a career-high for the young player and joining Ozzie Newsome as the only rookie tight ends in Browns history to record a 100-yard receiving game.

His blend of size, hands, and route-running ability makes him a matchup nightmare, and he is quickly solidifying his place as a core component of the Browns' offense for years to come. In an offense struggling for consistent playmakers, Fannin Jr.'s emergence is a major win.

Linebacker Devin Bush has been lights out for Jim Schwartz's defense this season.

Against the Titans, he added a key interception to his stat sheet, reading quarterback Cam Ward's eyes perfectly for a 44-yard return that set up a Browns scoring drive. Bush is playing like the dynamic, first-round pick the Steelers thought they were getting out of Michigan all those years ago.

Devin Bush intercepts Cam Ward!

TENvsCLE on FOX/FOX Onehttps://t.co/HkKw7uXVnt pic.twitter.com/adKxo8zSCL

In a league that values three-down linebackers, his strong, consistent performance this year, especially in coverage, has positioned him for a substantial contract in the upcoming free agency period.

The myth of the weather advantage was definitively debunked on Sunday. As the snow fell, the Titans' lead grew, largely due to the Browns' defense slipping and sliding all over the grass.

The conditions seemed to hamper Cleveland‚Äôs pursuit angles and tackling, leading to a career game from Titans running back Tony Pollard, who ran for 161 yards and two touchdowns.

Tony Pollard 65-yard TOUCHDOWN.

TENvsCLE on FOX/FOX Onehttps://t.co/HkKw7uXVnt pic.twitter.com/UZ9c5ifvfN

The Titans' effective ground-and-pound strategy mitigated the Browns' fearsome pass rush, turning the supposed home-field edge into a distinct disadvantage for the defense.

While Shedeur Sanders' tendency to hold onto the ball for a long time certainly allows for more pressure to be created, the offensive line is not without blame.

The unit's lack of consistency in play and availability has been a recurring and season-long problem, culminating in a performance where key starters suffered significant injuries. With starting center Ethan Pocic reportedly suffering a likely season-ending Achilles injury and other starters battling injuries, the unit is in shambles.

The team is likely looking to replace four of the five starters this offseason. A number that could be jumping to five of five if veteran left guard Joel Bitonio finally decides to hang up the cleats at season's end.

This article originally appeared on Browns Wire: Browns vs. Titans: 5 takeaways from Cleveland's NFL Week 14 loss

title: NHL Rumors: 3 Blackhawks On Latest Trade Board
description: Three Blackhawks have been featured on a new trade board.
fullText:
ESPN's Greg Wyshynski has released his latest trade board for ESPN, and three Chicago Blackhawks have made the cut: Jason Dickinson, Connor Murphy, and Laurent Brossoit.

Dickinson making this trade board is not particularly surprising. The 30-year-old center is a pending unrestricted free agent (UFA) and is the kind of player that playoff teams like to add at the trade deadline. This is because he is a solid veteran two-way forward who works on the penalty kill and also provides some grit. In 17 games so far this season, he has recorded two goals, three assists, five points, and a 52.3 faceoff winning percentage.

Like Dickinson, Murphy is another Blackhawks pending UFA who should grab the attention of clubs. It is no secret that playoff teams are always on the hunt for big right-shot defenseman, and Murphy fits that description. Because of this, the veteran defensive defenseman should be a popular target if the Blackhawks make him available near the deadline.

As for Brossoit, it is not a secret that they have been looking to find him a new home. The 32-year-old goaltender is currently on a conditioning assignment with the Rockford IceHogs, where he is playing in his first game action since the 2023-24 season.

title: Acerbi and Calhanoglu injury updates as Inter release statement
description: Inter say that Francesco Acerbi has suffered a ‚Äòstrain in his right thigh‚Äô and, according to reports in Italy, he‚Äôll remain out of action for circa one month, while Hakan Calhanoglu could return...
fullText:
Inter say that Francesco Acerbi has suffered a ‚Äòstrain in his right thigh‚Äô and, according to reports in Italy, he‚Äôll remain out of action for circa one month, while Hakan Calhanoglu could return in time for next week‚Äôs Supercoppa.

Inter released an official injury update on Acerbi, two days after the Italian was subbed off in a Champions League match against Liverpool.

PISA, ITALY ‚Äì NOVEMBER 30: Michel Aebischer of Pisa Sporting Club in action against Francesco Acerbi of FC Internazionale during the Serie A match between Pisa SC and FC Internazionale at Arena Garibaldi on November 30, 2025 in Pisa, Italy. (Photo by Gabriele Maltinti/Getty Images)

‚ÄúFrancesco Acerbi underwent a medical examination at the Istituto Humanitas di Rozzano this morning. The tests revealed a muscle strain in his right thigh,‚Äù the Nerazzurri said on Thursday.

According to Sky Sport Italia (via Calciomercato.com), it‚Äôs predictable that Acerbi will be forced to the sidelines for at least one month, given the nature of his injury.

This means that the Italy international will miss next week‚Äôs Supercoppa Italiana Final Four.

MILAN, ITALY ‚Äì DECEMBER 06: Hakan Calhanoglu of FC Internazionale Milano celebrates scoring his team‚Äôs third goal during the Serie A match between FC Internazionale and Como 1907 at Giuseppe Meazza Stadium on December 06, 2025 in Milan, Italy. (Photo by Marco Luzzani/Getty Images)

Calhanoglu was also subbed off due to an injury against Liverpool, but in his case, the Nerazzurri doctors didn‚Äôt order medical examinations, as the Turkish star is only dealing with a minor fitness problem.

Nevertheless, Calhanoglu is still expected to miss the next Serie A match against Genoa and return to action for the Supercoppa next week.

title: Dortmund's Schlotterbeck: Draw wasn't bitter, it was simply bad
description: Borussia Dortmund defender Nico Schlotterbeck sharply criticized his own team after they conceded a 2-2 draw to Bod√∏/Glimt in the Champions League on Wednesday evening. "We're playing in the Champions League, it (the performance) wasn't enough.
fullText:
Borussia Dortmund defender Nico Schlotterbeck sharply criticized his own team after they conceded a 2-2 draw to Bod√∏/Glimt in the Champions League on Wednesday evening.

"We're playing in the Champions League, it (the performance) wasn't enough. This is not bitter, it's simply bad," he said after the game.

"We played incredibly sloppily in the last quarter of an hour. That‚Äôs not good enough in a home game," he added.

Dortmund had the lead twice, but had to settle for the draw and share a point with the guests.

"We could have gone up to 13 points today. Killing the game is a matter of quality," Schlotterbeck continued.

"The players that came on in lost every ball. When you come on in the 60th minute, I expect 30 minutes of full throttle. After their second goal, we didn't have any more chances to score. We played incredibly sloppily in the last quarter of an hour," he said, with sharp words for his team-mates.

Coach Niko Kovac initially didn't want to comment on Schlotterbeck's statements. However, Kovac criticized similar things, according to sporting director Sebastian Kehl.

"The players should be aware of what they have gambled away here today," said Kehl, who spoke of a certain "arrogance."

On Thursday, however, Kovac said he could understand Schlotterbeck's frustration.

"As a leader, he surely has the right to speak out about certain things. I have nothing to add to that," Kovac said in a news conference.

"We missed a huge opportunity. That was completely unnecessary. It's completely normal that he, as a leading player, is angry about the behaviour."

Dortmund are 10th in the standings, which would only give them a spot in the play-offs for the knock-out rounds, but not direct qualification to the last 16.

On Sunday, they shift their focus back to the Bundesliga with a trip to Freiburg.

"Playing in Freiburg isn't easy. We expect them to be dangerous from set pieces. We'll have to be extremely careful. We need to respond after yesterday's game. That's what I expect from my team," Kovac said.

Dortmund are third in the domestic league, nine points behind leaders Bayern Munich.

title: 40-year-old LeBron James turns back the clock with poster dunk for Lakers vs. Spurs
description: Look out below.
fullText:
40-year-old LeBron James turns back the clock with poster dunk for Lakers vs. Spurs originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

LeBron James may not be as good as he once was, but he's as good once as he ever was.

Those Toby Keith lyrics, repurposed for this moment, certainly fit what the Los Angeles Lakers' 40-year-old superstar did on Wednesday night.

With an open trip down the lane, James gathered speed like the freight train of old.

He didn't appear bothered one bit by the presence of the gigantic Luke Kornet waiting at the rim for the San Antonio Spurs.

James, who turns 41 in three weeks, rose up and thundered down a poster dunk, no questions asked.

40-YEAR OLD LEBRON POSTER ON 7'1 LUKE KORNET ü§Øüî•

UNREAL. pic.twitter.com/ekPdfMwjsR

‚Äî Bleacher Report (@BleacherReport) December 11, 2025

Maybe his streak of double-digit points is over.

Maybe he's not the first option on his team anymore.

But this is still LeBron James. And he's still got it.

What other 40-year-old in the history of the planet is doing that? None. Zero. Zilch. Nada.

That's King behavior right there.

It was the NBA Cup quarterfinals, and James wasn't holding back. The Lakers went to halftime with a deficit, but they also went to the half with this highlight.

And even in a career full of moments like this, watching LeBron do that at this stage is still remarkable.

title: Did Yankees just put Anthony Volpe on notice for 2026? | Klapisch
description: The Yankees' shortstop, currently recovering from shoulder surgery, may have serious competition for his job in 2026.
fullText:
ORLANDO, Fla. ‚Äî Anthony Volpe is one of the brighter players in the Yankees clubhouse ‚Äî he would‚Äôve ended up at Vanderbilt as the Plan B out of high school ‚Äî so I‚Äôm confident the news from the Winter Meetings on Wednesday was not lost on the 24-year-old.

General manager Brian Cashman effectively announced the shortstop position is up for grabs next season. A report also emerged from The Dallas Morning News indicating the Yankees had checked in with the Rangers about shortstop Corey Seager. Both developments came within the span of a few hours.

The warning should be clear: The goodwill from the front office is now bundled with a deadline for 2026.

It‚Äôs time for Volpe to finally become the stud the Yankees thought they drafted in 2019.

‚ÄúThe game separates it all, the men from the boys (and) dictates who should and who shouldn‚Äôt be playing,‚Äù said Cashman as one of several money quotes.

‚ÄúPeople continue to earn their playing time or they don‚Äôt,‚Äù Cashman said.

‚ÄúIf it‚Äôs competition of the guys on the club, may the best man win and keep it, the general manager said.

Cashman made sure to ask and answer his own question about Volpe ‚Äî ‚ÄúDo I believe in Anthony Volpe? The answer is yes,‚Äù ‚Äî but didn‚Äôt let that vote of confidence stand on its own.

That‚Äôs because utilityman Jose Caballero has ascended to the Yankees‚Äô circle of trust. He has a legitimate chance to replace Volpe.

Listen to Cashman acknowledge the battle is on:

‚ÄúDo I believe Caballero has got a lot of talent? The answer is yes,‚Äù Cashman said.

The head-to-head battle, as riveting as it sounds, will have to wait a bit. Volpe is still recuperating from shoulder surgery and won‚Äôt be fully healed until late April or maybe early May.

But that‚Äôll give Caballero the time and exposure to convince the Yankees he‚Äôs more than just a charismatic role player. In a tale of the tape, Caballero is the better defender and base stealer, while Volpe has more power and ‚Äî that maddening word ‚Äî potential.

We‚Äôve been hearing about his upside since 2023. Yet, three years later, Volpe‚Äôs average is still stuck in the .220s for his career while he‚Äôs regressed in the field.

No American League player committed more errors than Volpe‚Äôs 19 in 2025. Volpe, in fact, was arguably MLB‚Äôs worst everyday player.

His surgery only further complicates matters. There‚Äôs no guarantee Volpe will be himself even after an all-clear from the doctors.

Torn labrums are no joke. They heal slowly and sometimes not entirely. Orthopedists say repairing that particular tendon has only a 75% success rate. Luckily for the right-handed Volpe, it‚Äôs his left shoulder that‚Äôs being rebuilt.

Throwing and swinging the bat will be unaffected. It‚Äôs diving for ground balls up the middle ‚Äî re-creating the very move that tore Volpe‚Äôs shoulder in the first place ‚Äî that poses the greatest risk for re-injury.

Cashman said Volpe is ‚Äúdoing well‚Äù in his third month of physical therapy at Yankee Stadium. The shortstop has headed down to Tampa to continue his rehab for the rest of the off-season.

The heavy lifting now rests with the front office. Sooner or later, Cashman will have to make a call on Volpe‚Äôs future.

The process begins with a searing question: What kind of player is Volpe, really, and how good can he be?

Yankees manager Aaron Boone, who‚Äôs stood behind the kid for the last three years, offered a surprisingly candid answer.

‚ÄúUltimately, we want to try to get more production out of (Volpe),‚Äù after explaining that all tweaks, changes in approach and philosophy have failed to move the needle.

Volpe is still 30-40 points below the Yankees‚Äô projections. His periodic home runs ‚Äî some in the biggest moments ‚Äî have been swallowed up by monster slumps and careless errors.

Something has to give. Either Volpe becomes a latter-day prime DJ LeMahieu, powering line drives the other way ‚Äî or he becomes an airtight asset at short.

Either one of these paths can save Volpe‚Äôs career in New York. But he can‚Äôt whiff on both. And the audition won‚Äôt last much longer. Volpe needs to have a breakthrough in 2026.

Perhaps the Yankees won‚Äôt wait even that long. The news of the club‚Äôs interest in Seager means one of two things:

1 ‚Äî Either Cashman called the Rangers out of due diligence and nothing more. General managers routinely send out feelers. Most conversations go nowhere.

2 ‚Äî Or else Cashman‚Äôs support for Volpe isn‚Äôt so firm. It‚Äôs noteworthy that he initiated the dialogue with Texas, not the other way around.

And the fact that he asked about the very player who could solve the Yankees‚Äô problem at shortstop? That‚Äôs not a coincidence.

Seager is 31, a borderline elite hitter with formidable power. He blasted 30-plus home runs three years in a row (2022-24) before injuries limited him to 21 last year.

He‚Äôs solid in the field, a notch below the game‚Äôs best shortstops.

There‚Äôs a catch, though. Seager is still owed $189 million through 2031 after signing a 10-year, $325 million deal that started in 2022. And then there‚Äôs the issue of how to re-arrange the infield to make room for him.

Trading second baseman Jazz Chisholm and moving Volpe to second base is one possibility. Or dealing Ryan McMahon (and undoubtedly pitcher Will Warren, too) and moving Chisholm to third. Volpe replaces Chisholm at second.

The Yankees would benefit from either one of these swaps. But that‚Äôs only if Yankees owner Hal Steinbrenner is willing to pay Seager $31.5 million a year.

So let‚Äôs all exhale. None of this will happen if Cody Bellinger returns. Steinbrenner isn‚Äôt rich enough to afford Bellinger and Seager in the same off-season.

Yankees fans mad about payroll? Here‚Äôs Brian Cashman‚Äôs response

title: Jumbo Package: Kalen DeBoer rumors are an unneeded distraction
description: Your latest Crimson Tide news and notes.
fullText:
As Brent covered last night, Michigan fired head coach Sherrone Moore after a bizarre and dark episode that could very easily have turned tragic. Kalen DeBoer was immediately named as a top target, despite his assurances to Alabama fans earlier this season that Tuscaloosa is a place that college football coaches just don‚Äôt leave.

Dennis Franchione would disagree. Look, none of us can know what Kalen is thinking. What we do know is that Michigan is a blue blood program with plenty of money, it‚Äôs much closer to Kalen‚Äôs South Dakota roots, and Ryan Grubb‚Äôs wife is a Michigan alum from Detroit who still works in Michigan. Courtney Morgan is a Michigan alum who curiously left his alma mater in 2022 after one year in the GM role, to join DeBoer at Washington.

You can bet that Michigan has already been in talks with Jimmy Sexton about DeBoer. He is going to get a handsome offer, and if he stays then Alabama fans know that he truly wants to be here. But, Alabama also may not be willing to match an outrageous offer if the Wolverines are desperate enough to make one.

And this is just the kind of distraction that the team doesn‚Äôt need.

In any case, there is a game to be played in eight days. Katie Windham wrote about some areas that need improvement, the offensive line chief among them.

So many of Alabama‚Äôs offensive issues start up front. Alabama has not been able to run the ball well all year and finished with negative rushing yards against Georgia in the SEC title game. Pass protection hasn‚Äôt been great either as Alabama is ranked 86th in the country with 25 sacks allowed. It seemed like Simpson was being pressured almost every time he dropped back to pass going up against the Georgia defensive front.

Alabama has been dealing with some issues on the offensive line with center Parker Brailsford not at full health¬†according to DeBoer. Guard Geno VanDeMark has also missed time with injury. Regardless of who is available for the CFP, the play has to be better overall. Of course, there needs to be improvement from Simpson and all of Alabama‚Äôs running backs, but help from the line will only make the other units on offense better.

Nick Kelly notes that, absent injury, changing quarterbacks at this stage isn‚Äôt the answer for this team.

Did Simpson miss some throws in the Georgia game? Yes. Could he have played better? Yes.

But was he the No. 1 problem for the offense in the Georgia game? No. Not even close.

Alabama‚Äôs receivers had their worst game of the season in the SEC Championship Game. They dropped 20.8% of the passes, per Pro Football Focus. That was the highest since the Florida State game, when the Crimson Tide dropped 14.8%. Alabama had six drops in the SEC Championship Game alone after 14 total in prior conference games.

Meanwhile, Simpson faced the most pressure he‚Äôs seen in any SEC game. Georgia pressured him 18 times, per PFF. The previous SEC high was 15 times against Missouri.

Before anyone starts about Tua and Jalen, times were much different then. Alabama was still blowing the doors off of most SEC teams, which gave Tua substantially more experience at this point of the season than either of Alabama‚Äôs 2025 backups. Throwing Austin Mack or Keelon Russell to the wolves in the playoffs just doesn‚Äôt make any sense.

Paul Myerberg is already firing off predictions, and he believes that Alabama beats Oklahoma before succumbing to Indiana.

No. 9 Alabama 21, No. 8 Oklahoma 16:¬†Oklahoma won the earlier matchup in Tuscaloosa, sparking the¬†Sooners‚Äô late rebirth as a playoff contender. Look for this one to be a low-scoring, defense-focused affair defined by which team wins the turnover battle. That favors the Tide, but only barely.

Emilee Smarr continues the series celebrating Alabama‚Äôs first national title in 1925.

The starters who carried¬†Alabama football¬†to its first national title in 1925 are celebrated in the program‚Äôs history, but the foundation of that legendary squad was laid just as much by the depth of its backups.

These players ‚Äì a mix of future stars, versatile workhorses and determined reserve players battling through injury ‚àí made sure the¬†Crimson Tide¬†wouldn‚Äôt be one-and-done, many going on to take the field in the program‚Äôs 1926 national championship. From eventual team captains to track stars, NFL champions and local legends, their contributions stretched beyond the stat sheet and etched the identity of Alabama football.

Last, Notre Dame‚Äôs hissy fit is beyond the pale. They initially garnered sympathy thanks to the committee‚Äôs rug pull on them, but they have quickly reminded the college football world just how entitled they are.

Perhaps things would have been different if Southern Cal was a little better or Syracuse hadn‚Äôt fallen apart or Purdue was further along in its rebuild. But no program, even Notre Dame, can truly position itself to win a national championship in this playoff era with two or three decent games a year, most of them early in the season.

And it‚Äôs probably going to get worse, especially if Notre Dame can‚Äôt come to an agreement with USC to extend their longstanding rivalry. Texas, also smarting from missing the CFP, has made noise about canceling its series with Notre Dame in 2028-29. Athletic directors in other leagues, who learned from Yahoo Sports‚Äô Ross Dellenger on Sunday about the memorandum of understanding that¬†grants Notre Dame preferential playoff access, are threatening to freeze them out of future schedules.

Notre Dame brass has reportedly reached out to both the Big Ten and SEC, but neither is likely to give them the sweetheart deal they got with the ACC. Still, Notre Dame independence may not sustain much longer.

That‚Äôs about it for now. Have a great day.

title: Why the Detroit Lions present unique challenge to Rams‚Äô offense
description: The Detroit Lions defensive tendencies make for an fascinating matchup against the 13 personnel-heavy Los Angeles Rams.
fullText:
One of the bigger narratives surrounding the Los Angeles Rams‚Äô explosive offense is their newfound love of 13 personnel‚Äîone running back, three tight end sets. The Rams almost never used 13 personnel under head coach Sean McVay‚Äîonly 84 times during McVay‚Äôs first nine seasons. But this year, the Rams lead the NFL in plays with 13 personnel, with a whopping 170 snaps‚Äîor 21.4% of the time. The league average 5.25%.

Last week against the Arizona Cardinals, that number jumped to 60%. Why? Well, the Rams‚Äô offense has been trending in that direction more and more as of late. It also loosens the load off of their explosive receiving corps, and with the Rams jumping out to a big lead last Sunday, they wanted to drain the clock with their running game.

But McVay also noted that with the way the Cardinals were playing the Rams‚Äîstubbornly staying in nickel (five defensive backs)‚Äîthey knew they‚Äôd be able to run the ball against Arizona.

‚ÄúThey came out in a lighter grouping and they basically dared you to run it based on what they were doing,‚Äù McVay said Tuesday. ‚ÄúAnd to the guys‚Äô credit, (center) Coleman (Shelton), the offensive line, Matthew (Stafford), and the rest of the tight ends and the receivers on the field, they did a good job of being able to recognize it and get good, efficient runs early on.‚Äù

The Rams finished with 249 rushing yards 6.9 yards per carry, and three rushing touchdowns against the Cardinals. Per SumerSports, the Rams rank top-10 in both passing (0.34 EPA/pass, eighth) and rushing efficiency (0.13 EPA/rush, fourth) out of 13 personnel.

Detroit Lions coach Dan Campbell knows of another benefit to using so much 13 personnel. It helps tip off what the defense is going to do.

‚ÄúI think there‚Äôs predictability in¬†13, normally you know what you‚Äôre going to get,‚Äù Campbell said. ‚ÄúSometimes in 12, you don‚Äôt know if you‚Äôre going to get nickel or base defense. So, that‚Äôs another reason. They know what they‚Äôre going to attack. They know probably the defense, the fronts, the coverages, that helps. And they‚Äôve got tight ends. They‚Äôve got some tight ends that are versatile and do a little bit of everything, that‚Äôs always going to help.‚Äù

In short, 13 personnel forces more defenses to play in base (four defensive backs), which gives the offense an advantage knowing they‚Äôll be facing heavier personnel‚Äîwhich many opponents may not want to do.

But the Lions are different. Detroit lives in heavy, base formations more often than any other team‚Äîregardless of what offenses are throwing at them. Per Sharp Football, the Lions live in subpackages (like nickel) at the lowest rate in football (35%). They believe they have the personnel to be able to stop the run and defend the pass with three linebackers on the field. And so they don‚Äôt view 13 personnel as a particular threat to get them out of their comfort zone.

‚ÄúWhen I hear a lot of 13 personnel, that they‚Äôre trying to dictate stuff,‚Äù Lions linebacker Jack Campbell said on Wednesday. ‚ÄúBecause you only have a limited menu (against 13). I can‚Äôt speak for other defenses in the NFL, but usually you have a limited menu in 13 personnel, because not a lot of teams run it. You‚Äôre going to get base (defense) out there. You‚Äôre going to probably get three linebackers out there, which we play a majority of the time. So it‚Äôs not really going to matter.‚Äù

Jack Campbell admitted the Rams operate out of 13 personnel in a very complicated way, often using their players much like they would in 12 or even 11 personnel, because their tight end group is extremely talented and versatile. But, again, he reiterated that the Lions‚Äô defense is uniquely prepared against 13 looks.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going to be a challenge, but at the same time, it‚Äôs not really‚Äîin my opinion‚Äîgoing to affect us terribly, just because I feel like we‚Äôre used to playing with three linebackers already,‚Äù Jack Campbell continued. ‚ÄúWe kinda have some calls into that. We can mesh it on in, and the guys who are out there are versatile players.‚Äù

Of course, McVay already knows Detroit‚Äôs tendency to stay in base. So it wouldn‚Äôt be surprising to see the Rams play a little less 13 against the Lions defense. For as much attention as they‚Äôre getting in 13 personnel, McVay offenses are more historically defined by their heavy use of 11 personnel (three wide receivers). And despite their recent uptick in 13, the Rams still use 11 personnel at the eighth-highest rate in the NFL this year (66.8%).

But they aren‚Äôt as efficient running the ball out of those sets (0.03 EPA/rush, 17th), meaning the Lions could force them out of their comfort zone on Sunday, as long as they remain a strong run defense in base. And if the Lions can slow the Rams‚Äô rushing attack, it could be the key to pulling off a big road upset.

title: Champions League review: Liverpool sidestep Salah saga as Chelsea slip up
description: Manchester City conquer the Bernab√©u, Liverpool survive without Mohamed Salah and Atalanta find Chelsea‚Äôs flaws
fullText:
‚Ä¢ To say that Pep Guardiola and Real Madrid have history is to put it mildly. At Barcelona, Guardiola grew up amid an obsessive enmity on both sides, one deepened by his term as the Catalan club‚Äôs coach. They are highly familiar with Manchester City, too. City met Madrid for the fifth season in succession on Wednesday. Despite Madrid‚Äôs recent struggles under Xabi Alonso, winning at the Santiago Bernab√©u is a huge result, a deserved win where City might have been out of sight by half-time. Rodrygo scored his habitual goal against City but one of Guardiola‚Äôs new generation in Nico O‚ÄôReilly equalised before a controversial penalty award, converted by Erling Haaland, decided the game. A player linked with a move to Madrid sometime in the distant future celebrated with a smirk; Jude Bellingham‚Äôs attempt to distract by trying to yank Haaland‚Äôs ponytail did not work. After the selection misstep that led to defeat to Bayer Leverkusen, Guardiola got it right in Madrid to leave a lifelong rival in flux. In acknowledging an opponent wracked by injury and infighting had made for an easier task than usual, high standards came to the fore. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been here [at the Bernab√©u] many times in the last five years and we have played much better than today and not won,‚Äù Guardiola said. He talks ‚Äì and his team plays ‚Äì like he has his mojo back.

‚Ä¢ No Mohamed Salah, taking gym selfies back on Merseyside, but the Champions League continued to be a haven for Liverpool and Arne Slot. If you can‚Äôt find it, grind it? Pre-season hopes of a forward line costing over half a billion dollars carving through opposition are set aside in the hustle for results. Beating Inter at San Siro was crucial for resetting the equilibrium imbalanced by Salah‚Äôs weekend outburst. ‚ÄúAll I could ask for,‚Äù said Slot, an inadvertent victor of the Salah saga, maintaining diplomacy by concentrating on those players who travelled to Milan. ‚ÄúOnly 14 outfield players available with Premier League or Champions League experience ‚Ä¶ tonight it should be all about the players that are here.‚Äù Slot reserved high praise for Ibrahima Konat√©, who starred amid his troubled season. It was Dominik Szoboszlai who converted the decisive, if controversial, penalty. In a season of flux, Szoboszlai‚Äôs positive influence has been a happy constant.

‚Ä¢ The English response to Atalanta‚Äôs defeat of Chelsea was to voice concerns about Enzo Maresca‚Äôs team‚Äôs wild inconsistencies. The broader, continental view is to appreciate the continued rise of the Serie A club from Bergamo. It was only last month that Ivan Juric was sacked after just five months in charge ‚Äì marginally longer than the Croat lasted at Southampton ‚Äì after a seven-game winless run in the league. His successor, Raffaele Palladino, has instigated a revival including successive Champions League wins, beating Chelsea following the defeat of Eintracht Frankfurt. Gianluca Scamacca, formerly of West Ham, cancelled out Jo√£o Pedro‚Äôs opener from Charles De Ketelaere‚Äôs cross. While Robert S√°nchez‚Äôs goalkeeping was suspect for the winner, De Ketelaere‚Äôs solo run had carved Chelsea wide open. ‚ÄúAn amazing feeling, with the fans behind us, against the champions of the world,‚Äù said De Ketelaere, one of the best of Belgium‚Äôs new generation. Atalanta continue to be an admired nursery of talent who also deliver results. Even though the talismanic coach Gian Piero Gasperini is now at Roma, the 2024 Europa League winners are well-set for automatic qualification.

Jules Kound√©, from right-back, notched two headers as Barcelona mounted a comeback to beat Eintracht Frankfurt 2-1, the first assisted by Marcus Rashford, the second by Lamine Yamal; the first time a Bar√ßa player has scored two headers in the competition. Other nominees include De Ketelaere, Arsenal‚Äôs Noni Madueke for his double in Bruges and Ajax‚Äôs Israeli winger Oscar Gloukh, who also scored twice, against Qarabag, for his club‚Äôs first win.

‚ÄúThanks, Nicky ... shame on you,‚Äù read a banner displayed by Club Brugge fans during their 3-0 home defeat to Arsenal. It was a protest after Nicky Hayen, their popular coach, was sacked on Monday. ‚ÄúNot our club,‚Äù read a series of handmade signs. The coach who masterminded a league title in 2023-24, and the Belgian club‚Äôs fine showings in the Champions League last season, had been linked with the Celtic vacancy. His replacement, Ivan Leko, declaring himself a Hayen admirer, said: ‚ÄúThe supporters‚Äô banners? Honestly, I‚Äôm proud of them.‚Äù

On beINSports‚Äôs broadcast to the Middle East and North Africa, Ruud Gullit leapt to the defence of Jude Bellingham at Real Madrid, dismissing Richard Keys‚Äôs trenchant opinions. ‚ÄúHe can‚Äôt play in the same way he could when [Toni] Kroos was there. When he and [Federico] Valverde are there, they have balance. Now it has to be another guy,‚Äù said Gullit, who claimed the Englishman was being sold short by all-star colleagues not tracking back.

Keys responded: ‚ÄúHe is an agitator, not a victim. He might be [a great player], but there‚Äôs a reason that Thomas Tuchel won‚Äôt pick him.‚Äù

Gullit hit back: ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a ridiculous suggestion. He is the best player they have. He just wants to win.‚Äù

‚Ä¢ Napoli meanwhile, are 23rd in the table, and play Copenhagen in 24th next time out. Antonio Conte‚Äôs Champions League record pales into insignificance compared to his domestic titles. ‚ÄúI know how much we have spent both physically and mentally,‚Äù he said of his side‚Äôs weekend victory against Juventus, in justification for the 2-0 defeat to Benfica in Lisbon.

‚Ä¢ Is late-stage Jos√© Mourinho performing a miracle? Benfica, inherited winless and pointless in the Champions League, moved to 25th after beating Napoli, and he enjoyed a barb at his old rival Conte. ‚ÄúSaying Benfica were fresher physically feels like an excuse,‚Äù said Mourinho. Next up are another familiar foe in Juventus. Following that, Real Madrid. ‚ÄúCharacter and intelligence, a Benfica mentality,‚Äù is how Mourinho envisages his club reaching the knockouts.

‚Ä¢ As for Juventus, their timely 2-0 win against Pafos came courtesy of Weston McKennie‚Äôs goal and a strike from Canada‚Äôs Jonathan David. McKennie‚Äôs brilliant effort was the 50th scored by a USMNT player in the Champions League. All eyes on that new year meeting with Benfica.

title: Nik Bonitto chasing Von Miller's single-season franchise sack record
description: Nik Bonitto still aims to break Von Miller's single-season sack record with the Broncos. He's six sacks away from tying it.
fullText:
While the Denver Broncos' defense approaches the NFL's single-season sack record, outside linebacker Nik Bonitto is chasing an individual franchise record.

Von Miller -- Bonitto's childhood idol -- holds Denver's individual single-season record with 18.5 sacks (set in 2012). Bonitto, who is the team's first player since Miller to record double-digit sacks in consecutive seasons, hopes to surpass Miller's franchise record.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs within range, but it‚Äôs going to be tough," Bonitto told the Denver Gazette's Chris Tomasson. "I‚Äôm going to have to have some good ones over the last couple of games. So we‚Äôll see."

Bonitto has 12.5 sacks through 13 games. If he continues that current pace, he'd end the year with about 16 to 16.5 sacks, just shy of Miller's record. Bonitto would have to average more than 1.5 sacks per game over the final four weeks to break the record.

Up next¬†on Denver's schedule¬†are Jordan Love (18 sacks), Trevor Lawrence (32 sacks), Patrick Mahomes (29 sacks) and Justin Herbert (45 sacks). Combined, those QBs average 2.38 sacks per game. Earlier this season, Bonitto totaled two sacks against Herbert (Week 3) and none against Mahomes (Week 11).

Social: Follow¬†Broncos Wire¬†on¬†Facebook¬†and¬†Twitter/X!¬†Did you know:¬†These 25 celebrities are Broncos fans.

This article originally appeared on Broncos Wire: Denver Broncos: Nik Bonitto chasing Von Miller's sack record

title: Cantwell has shown he is a leader - Ismael
description: Blackburn Rovers boss Valerien Ismael believes their results will now improve with the return to fitness of captain Todd Cantwell.
fullText:
The return of captain Todd Cantwell will see an upturn in results for Blackburn Rovers, says boss Valerien Ismael.

Rovers are currently 20th in the Championship table with just one win from their past six matches as they prepare to visit fellow strugglers Portsmouth on Saturday (15:00 GMT).

Cantwell, 27, returned from a two-month absence with a knee injury at the start of December and has appeared as a substitute in the draws with Ipswich Town and Oxford United, scoring a penalty against the U's on Tuesday.

"We've found the way and the shape for this team, and we have the position for Toddy as well, which is really good," Ismael told BBC Radio Lancashire.

"He was on an unbelievable level before his injury. Now he's back we still need to manage him. Every time it's a closed discussion with him - how he feels and how long he thinks he can play."

Ismael also believes handing the club captaincy to Cantwell following the departure of Lewis Travis in August has brought a new dimension from the forward.

"At the beginning of the season when I made the decision, I had a long discussion with him. For almost one hour, we discussed everything," Ismael added.

"I think the responsibility was a big lift for him, he wanted that.

"He came to a point in his life where he wanted to prove to himself that he's able to do that, to change maybe the image that people have got of him [that he's a] soft player and not consistent with a lot of quality, and I think he's shown that he's a leader."

Ismael is hopeful midfielder Sondre Tronstad could return for the trip to Fratton Park while goalkeeper Balazs Toth and midfielder Ryan Hedges could be involved against Millwall on December 20.

title: Justin Herbert injury: Chargers QB provides update on hand
description: Chargers quarterback Justin Herbert was a limited participant in Wednesday's practice.
fullText:
Quarterback Justin Herbert underwent precautionary postgame X-rays on his fractured left hand after the Chargers' win over the Eagles, which came back "clean for the most part".

The X-rays were taken to ensure that no further damage occurred during the game in which he played with a protective glove. On Wednesday, Herbert stated that his hand is feeling much better this week compared to last, and his focus is on reducing swelling and improving grip strength.

Herbert mentioned the hand was still sore, saying that playing on it, using it, and falling on it during the Monday night game were likely the causes for the soreness.

Herbert finished the game as the team's leading rusher, logging 66 yards on ten carries. He wasn't as prolific as usual in the passing department, completing 12 of 26 passes for 136 yards. But most of the lack of production was due to the Eagles' stifling defense, which locked up the Bolts' receivers and consistently pressured him.

"I missed a lot of throws and played uncharacteristically. There's a bunch of plays that I'd love to have back," Herbert said.

Herbert was a limited participant in Wednesday's practice but is expected to play in this Sunday's game against the Chiefs.

This article originally appeared on Chargers Wire: Justin Herbert injury: Chargers QB provides update on hand

title: Dragos Cazacu signs with Tennessee
description: Tennessee announces the signing of graduate student Dragos Cazacu.
fullText:
Tennessee announced the signing of graduate student Dragos Cazacu on Wednesday. He is from Constanta, Romania.

"Dragos is someone we believe can translate all of his professional experience and success seamlessly to high level college tennis," Tennessee associate head coach Matt Lucas said. "He's a very mature young man who has finished university in Romania, so we know the type of student athlete we are getting. Winning ITF Pro Circuit titles, all while doing his degree back home shows he will transition nicely to Tennessee in January."

Cazacu competed on the ATP Tour prior to Tennessee. His highest ranking was No. 763 in singles and No. 495 in doubles.

Tennessee will begin its spring men's tennis season versus ETSU on Jan. 9, 2026 at Goodfriend Tennis Center. SEC competition will begin Feb. 21, 2026 at Kentucky.

The Vols' home opener in SEC play is scheduled for Feb. 27, 2026 versus Auburn at Goodfriend Tennis Center.

More: Tennessee tennis signs No. 1 ranked junior player

Follow Vols Wire on¬†Facebook¬†and¬†X¬†(formerly Twitter).

This article originally appeared on Vols Wire: Vols announce signing of graduate student Dragos Cazacu

fullText:

title: Thursday Night Football Odds: TNF Betting Lines 2025
description: We have the latest Thursday Night Football odds for 2025, with Week 15 featuring the Atlanta Falcons vs. Tampa Bay Buccaneers.
fullText:
After 74 total points in Week 14, the Thursday Night Football odds for Week 15 should also see more scoring action as the Atlanta Falcons visit the Tampa Bay Buccaneers ‚Äî two teams with better offenses than defenses.

Here are the latest look-ahead NFL odds for this game, so follow along for the latest TNF odds and TNF player props, plus the full TNF schedule for 2025.

Point spread: Falcons +6 | Buccaneers -6

Moneyline: Falcons +205 | Buccaneers -250

View all TNF passing props, including Kirk Cousins odds and Baker Mayfield odds.

View all TNF rushing props, including Bijan Robinson odds and Bucky Irving odds.

View all TNF receiving props, including Drake London odds and Emeka Egbuka odds.

Falcons vs. Buccaneers predictions

Falcons vs. Buccaneers prop picks

Falcons vs. Buccaneers same game parlay

Falcons vs. Buccaneers anytime touchdown scorer picks

Commanders (18) at Packers (27)

Seahawks (23) at Cardinals (20)

From¬†Jason Logan, Covers Senior Industry Analyst

Thursday games present a tight turnaround for the teams involved. Look back at the teams‚Äô recent schedule challenges and see if this short week compounds a busy calendar ‚Äî especially for the road team. Practice and prep time are at a premium during these short weeks... and they will lose a day to travel.

Thursday games also leave less time for teams to heal up. Injured players don‚Äôt have the same window for recovery and are often ruled out early. Even players nursing bumps and bruises, or playing through pain, can feel the squeeze of the short week, so read up on who‚Äôs hurting ‚Äî but not listed on the injury report.

Coaching can give a big edge on the short week. Give the benefit of the doubt to veteran coaches and experienced staff, who are known for their game prep and have navigated the challenges of TNF before.

Thursday night games can also be an advantage for cold weather teams come December and January. Temperatures plummet when the sun goes down and places like Green Bay, Chicago, and Buffalo turn into frozen wastelands. While the sub-zero temps impact both sides, visitors from warmer cities or indoor stadiums may struggle to adapt when the mercury drops.

Home-field advantage can get a bit of a boost on Thursday nights. The home crowd has been tailgating all day, rather than partying for a 1 p.m. or 4 p.m. ET kickoff. That ravenous crowd is then released into the stadium, giving the home hospitality a little extra bite.
